description: Uncertain; possibly from Old French giber (“to engage in horseplay; to play roughly in sport”). Compare English jib (“usually of a horse: to stop and refuse to go forward”), Old Norse geipa (“to talk nonsense”).
The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: A facetious or insulting remark; a jeer, a taunt.
examples: He flung subtle jibes at her until she couldn’t bear to work with him any longer.

verbs.description: jibe (third-person singular simple present jibes, present participle jibing, simple past and past participle jibed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reproach with contemptuous words; to deride, to mock, to taunt.
(transitive) To say in a mocking or taunting manner.
(intransitive) To make a mocking remark or remarks; to jeer.

description: Origin unknown; perhaps related to chime (“to cause to sound in harmony”).

verbs.description: jibe (third-person singular simple present jibes, present participle jibing, simple past and past participle jibed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Canada, US, informal) To accord or agree.
examples: That explanation doesn’t jibe with the facts.

entries.meaning: (nautical, now chiefly US) Alternative spelling of gybe

verbs.description: jibe (third-person singular simple present jibes, present participle jibing, simple past and past participle jibed)

entries.meaning: (nautical, now chiefly US) Alternative spelling of gybe
